TEXT: The applicant is a joint stock company which was established in DATE and has its registered office in GPE . Since DATE the name of the applicant company has been PERSON , a.s . It operates a mobile phone network in GPE . It is represented before the Court by PERSON , a lawyer practising in GPE . The respondent Government are represented by PERSON , their Agent .
The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .

Under a contract of DATE between the applicant company and ORG ( PERSON informačná služba – “ the SIS ” ) , which was supplemented by an annex of DATE , the applicant company cooperated with the ORG in its monitoring of telecommunication traffic ( “ interception ” ) in the applicant company ’s network . The cooperation included adjustments to the applicant company ’s switchboards .

At that time the ORG ’s role and powers of interception were laid down in LAW ( CARDINAL ) of LAW of DATE ( Law no . PERSON . , as amended ) . This provision contained no express rules as to who was to finance the interception and the equipment necessary for it ( “ interception equipment ” ) . According to the Government , however , the provision was in practice understood as imposing the duty to finance the interception equipment on the operators of telephone networks .

On DATE LAW ( Law no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL Coll . ) entered into force . It replaced LAW of DATE . Under section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) the applicant company had a duty towards lawenforcement and ORG defence and security authorities to provide , at its own cost , the means for interceptions in its network . The scope and technical specifications of the interception equipment were to be approved by ORG ( PERSON úrad PERSON republiky ) .

In a letter of DATE the ORG requested that ORG authorise an extension of the interception equipment used in the applicant company ’s network . The request concerned the existing equipment , which had been procured in DATE and now had to be extended on account of the expansion and modernisation of the applicant company ’s network . The police and ORG , who were also involved with interception , supported the request .
The request was granted on DATE , but the decision was quashed on DATE on appeal ( rozklad ) on account of formal shortcomings .

On DATE ORG held a hearing . It was attended by representatives of the applicant company , the ORG and the ministries of the interior , defence , justice , finance , and transportation , post and telecommunications .

On DATE a representative of the applicant company was allowed to consult the case file . Following the consultation , on DATE , ORG again authorised the extension sought . It was understood that , by virtue of section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) of LAW of DATE , it was the applicant company alone that was to bear the costs of the extension .

At the same time ORG ruled that the authorisation would become effective immediately even if the decision as such were to be appealed against . This ruling was based on the pressing general interest which ORG found in the need to ensure the proper functioning of the ORG organs and agencies whose task was to monitor telecommunications .
On DATE the Director of the ORG dismissed an appeal by the applicant company as unfounded .

The applicant company challenged the decisions of DATE and DATE by an administrativelaw action in ORG ( Najvyšší súd ) . As in the proceedings before ORG , the applicant company did not object to the duty to contribute to the financing of the interception equipment as such , but merely to the scope of that duty as established by ORG . The applicant company further argued that the procedure and the decisions had been arbitrarily classified as “ secret ” ; that the extension took no account of the applicant company ’s technical , staffing and financial capacity ; and that no cost - benefit analysis had been carried out . The extension was therefore at variance with the applicant company ’s property rights guaranteed under LAW and LAW .

On DATE the applicant company lodged an application requesting ORG to stay the proceedings under LAW ( b ) of LAW and initiate proceedings in ORG ( Ústavný súd ) with a view to reviewing the compliance of section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) of LAW of DATE with the relevant provisions of the LAW and with LAW No . CARDINAL .

On DATE ORG dismissed the action . It observed that ORG had held a hearing and that its decision had been delivered publicly . Classifying the proceedings as “ secret ” was not excluded by law and had not curtailed the applicant company ’s procedural rights . ORG also held that section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) of LAW of DATE unequivocally imposed on the applicant company the financial burden of the equipment in question . It was for ORG to specify the scope and technical features of the equipment , which it had rightly done . As to the applicant company ’s constitutional and LAW objections , ORG “ discerned no violation of the applicant company ’s constitutional rights ” . No decision was taken and no opinion was expressed in respect of the applicant company ’s application of DATE to stay the action and challenge the constitutionality of the relevant provisions of LAW of DATE . No appeal lay against that judgment and , upon service on the parties , it became final on DATE .
The applicant company complied with the above decisions and accordingly incurred financial expense .

In DATE the applicant company requested ORG to exercise his discretionary power to challenge section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) of LAW of DATE in ORG as being contrary to LAW and the Convention . The Prosecutor General acceded to the request .

On DATE LAW ( Law no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL Coll . ) entered into force . LAW ) ( j ) of that LAW provided for a similar duty in respect of financing interception equipment as section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) of LAW of DATE .

The Prosecutor General subsequently withdrew his constitutional challenge in respect of section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) of LAW and the proceedings in respect of it were discontinued without any decision being given on the merits .

In DATE the applicant company again requested ORG to exercise his discretionary power and challenge section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) ( j ) of LAW of DATE in ORG as being contrary to LAW and the Convention . From the official internet page of ORG ) it appears that ORG lodged the challenge on DATE and that it is still pending .
LAW ( a ) provides :

“ The Constitutional Court shall have jurisdiction to determine the compliance of statutes with the LAW , constitutional statutes and international treaties which have been assented to by ORG and ratified and promulgated in the manner required by statute . ”
Article CARDINAL , as in force from DATE , reads as follows :

“ CARDINAL . The Constitutional Court shall decide complaints by natural or juristic persons alleging a violation of their fundamental rights or freedoms or of human rights and fundamental freedoms enshrined in international treaties ratified by GPE ... unless the protection of such rights and freedoms falls within the jurisdiction of a different court .

CARDINAL . NORP If ORG finds a complaint justified , it shall deliver a decision stating that a person ’s rights or freedoms as set out in paragraph CARDINAL have been violated by a final decision , specific measure or other act and shall quash such decision , measure or act . If the violation that has been found is the result of a failure to act , ORG may order [ the authority ] which has violated the rights or freedoms to take the necessary action . At the same time it may remit the case to the authority concerned for further proceedings , order such authority to refrain from violating the fundamental rights and freedoms ... or , where appropriate , order those who have violated the rights or freedoms set out in paragraph CARDINAL to restore the situation to that existing prior to the violation .
CARDINAL . NORP In its decision on a complaint ORG may grant appropriate financial compensation to the person whose rights under paragraph CARDINAL have been violated .

CARDINAL . The liability for damage or other loss of a person who has violated another person ’s rights or freedoms within the meaning of paragraph CARDINAL shall not be affected by the Constitutional Court’ s decision . ”
Pursuant to LAW :
“ The Constitutional Court shall open proceedings on an application by
a ) no less than one fifth of the deputies of ORG ,
b ) the President of GPE ,
c ) the Government of GPE ,
d ) a court of law ,
e ) the Prosecutor General
f ) any person whose rights are the subject of proceedings under Articles CARDINAL and CARDINALa [ of the LAW ] . ”
Article PERSON provides :

“ CARDINAL . International treaties on human rights and fundamental freedoms ratified by GPE and promulgated in accordance with the statutory requirements existing prior to the entry into force of this constitutional law shall be part of the national legal order and take precedence over national laws provided that such international treaties guarantee more extensive constitutional rights and freedoms .

CARDINAL . Other international treaties ratified by GPE and promulgated under statutory requirements existing prior to the entry into force of this constitutional law shall be part of the national legal order if so provided by statute . ”
Details concerning the status of ORG and of the procedure before it are laid down in LAW .

Under LAW ( CARDINAL ) , which applies to all types of proceedings before ORG , as a general rule , the scope of ORG examination of a case is limited by the summary of the application for commencement of the proceedings , as formulated in a standardised and prescribed form by the plaintiff .
Specific rules applicable in respect of complaints under LAW are laid down in sections CARDINAL et seq .

Under section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) a constitutional complaint is not admissible if the complainant has not exhausted effective remedies that are available to him or her in respect of the rights and freedoms in question .

Section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) provides that a constitutional complaint can be lodged within DATE from the date on which the decision in question has become final and binding or on which a measure has been notified or on which notice of other interference has been given . As regards measures and other interferences , the above period commences when the complainant could have become aware of them .

A complaint under LAW , as in force from DATE , can not be directed against violations of fundamental rights which took place DATE ( see , for example , the decision of DATE , file no . II . ÚS CARDINAL/CARDINAL ) .

ORG has no power of alternative or extraordinary review in respect of matters DATE within the jurisdiction of the ordinary courts ( see , for example , the decision of DATE , file no . II . ÚS CARDINAL ) . As a matter of principle , ORG has no power to review factual findings and legal conclusions of the ordinary courts ( see , for example , decision of CARDINAL DATE , file no . II . ÚS CARDINAL ) or to scrutinise their interpretation and application of the law ( see , for example , decision of CARDINAL DATE , file no . I. ÚS CARDINAL/CARDINAL ) . The jurisdiction of ORG is subsidiary and applies only to matters that fall outside the jurisdiction of the ordinary courts ( see decision of DATE , file no . II ÚS CARDINAL/CARDINAL ) . ORG can examine decisions of the ordinary courts as such only if they are “ manifestly ill - founded or arbitrary ” ( see , for example , decision of DATE , file no . I. ÚS CARDINAL ) . Apart from that , ORG role is principally limited to examining whether the effects of the ordinary courts’ decisions are compatible with the LAW and applicable international instruments ( see , for example , decision of DATE , file no . I. CARDINAL/CARDINAL ) . If an incompatibility is found , the ORG exercises its power to quash the decision concerned and to award just satisfaction ( see , for example , judgments ( nález ) of DATE , CARDINAL DATE and DATE , file nos . I. ÚS CARDINAL/CARDINAL , III . ÚS CARDINAL/CARDINAL and III . ÚS CARDINAL/CARDINAL , respectively ) .

Ordinary courts are obliged in civil proceedings to interpret and apply the relevant laws in accordance with the LAW and with international treaties . Accordingly , the ordinary courts have the primary responsibility for upholding rights and fundamental freedoms guaranteed by the LAW or international treaties ( see , for example , the decision of DATE , file no . I. ÚS CARDINAL ) .

Any type of proceedings before ORG can only be commenced in a separate set of proceedings and only on the application of persons or bodies which have standing to initiate them . No type of constitutional proceedings can be instituted within proceedings of another type . An examination of a complaint under LAW can not entail a review of the constitutionality of legislation ( see , for example , decision of DATE , file no . II . ÚS CARDINAL ) .
